content: Hello everyone, my name is Joe McCann and I just learned about this project recently and began exploring the code / setting up on my device. While looking around and trying to run files I found that the generate_most_wanted_list.py is no longer functional due to the function parse_proofs_file having its signature changed. If the "most wanted list" script is still useful enough to warrant being fixed I could try fixing it as a "getting my feet wet" sort of thing; if its no longer relevant then perhaps it might be worthwhile deleting it?
Semi unrelated, but there's some minor QoL fixes that could be nice, such as creating a python virtual environment requirements folder and setup script. As well as potentially some unit tests.
Is there a task you would like to take up first?
The QoL issue is somewhat under-specified but if you create a well-defined issue with a good description then after some Zulip discussion I can make it a project task
One important point though, please make sure you don't change the scripts themselves without the authors and others knowing about it.

Totally fair. First QoL step would be

Python3 requirements.txt and venv setup: Create a requirements.txt file containing all necessary dependencies in order to run the python scripts within the repository, as well as a setup.sh script to create the python virtual environment and install the dependencies.

Also don't worry I will not make any changes out of the blue and fully intend on following all processes outline in the contributions document :D
Also is there a specific version of Python3 for this project that everyone is using?
The CI action blueprint.yml will have the details you seek
I am currently on a bus. So typing a more detailed response is hard

I see, is there a reason that we install each package individually instead of using a requirements.txt file? If not would totally be happy to make one and update the blueprint.yml action.

Also no worries, the bus is the bus haha.
No don't update blueprint, I just wanted to point out which python version we use is determined there

dont worry, wont touch anything without an assigned issue. I was just spit-balling.
I see from builds we got python 3.11 tyty
@Shreyas Srinivas am I ok to make a PR to create a python requirements.txt file / create an issue for said task and then open a PR?
obvs will never ever push directly to main, always will open a PR
This is a question to which all script creators need to respond since it affects how they run their scripts locally for development
But do create an issue and post it here
It can be discussed, and if there is consensus, it can become a project task
The PR can happen later

Hi @Joe McCann, it is on my TODO list. It's ready to push (I am working in a .venv myself). I agree that it's a good practice to add the requirements.txt file to enable quick and easy reproducibility of that part of the project.
We do need to pin python versions
Let's set up an issue and make it a project task @Joe McCann
And then we can see how the CI builds
Sure.
Sounds good, created https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/issues/572 and set myself to claim. This look good to y'all?
We need to make it a project task first
oop :eyes: my b
you can claim it now
Before merging the PR please ensure that the authors of all scripts inside the scripts folder agree with the change.

CC : @Pietro Monticone
I won't have time to review it
I’ll review it later tonight or tomorrow. Thanks a lot for your contribution.
The issue is perfectly fine. When you have a PR ready you just need to propose #PR_NUMBER and I’ll review it

Sounds good. PR proposed in 580. Used a new tool called pip-config to create the sub-dependencies list. Really liked it in researching so that we can see exactly what packages are necessary for what reason. I added some additional scrips to setup the Python environments on Windows and Unix as well.

(Not to enter the world of Python packaging tooling bikeshedding, just FYI, uv, which many of us in the Python community basically think is the right tool finally, also has a uv pip compile drop-in replacement for pip-compile which is miles faster and produces identical output on your branch, just in case you need to run it again. Also you mention it, but only putting direct dependencies in a requirements.txt is just wrong, all of them including transitive deps belong in it, as you've done.)

Sounds good to me. I am not married to pip-tools, I actually just learned about it when researching what good standards are, as I was accustomed to pip3 freeze > requirements.txt and just letting it rip lmao. I'll change to uv. That certainly caused headaches when corporate made us update package version numbers and we had to diagnose what was broken :skull:

Also, funny story. When I joined my first team the requirements file actually only listed out direct dependencies and no sub-dependencies. That also caused so many headaches and was something I was happy to fix whenever I got to work on a particular repo
Merged.
Pietro Monticone has marked this topic as resolved.

Hey @Pietro Monticone theres a bug in the requirements.txt file thats preventing installation through pip install. Theres also a lot of unnecessary packages in there. I am going to create a PR to fix it
seems like it was introduced today in a PR
Pietro Monticone has marked this topic as unresolved.
Sure. Feel free to open a PR. I’ll review it later.
https://github.com/teorth/equational_theories/pull/600 yep whenever you get the chance here it is. Ty
Merged.
Pietro Monticone has marked this topic as resolved.
